anchor.surface_text: s. 20 2  of the Act reads as follows-- Section 20.- Recovery of money due from an employer under an award or decision.  1  Where any workman is entitled to receive from the empoly- er any benefit under an award or decision of an industrial tribunal which is capable of being computed in terms of money, the amount at which such benefit should be computed may, subject to the rules made under this Act, be determined by that industrial tribunal,

arguments.claim: Reinstatement benefit is not a term of the contract; effect is to continue original contract as if no wrongful dismissal

anchor.surface_text: The benefit of reinstatement which is awarded to a workman under the terms of the award does not become a term or condition of the contract between him and the employer. There is no doubt other reliefs by way of changes in the terms and conditions of employment which when awarded by the appropriate tribunal might be treated as implied terms of the contract between the employer and the workers to whom the award applies and would enure for the benefit of the worker until varied by appropriate legal proceedings.

arguments.claim: Ordinary master-servant damages principles apply by analogy but distinguished; no damages for feelings; mitigation required

anchor.surface_text: The position- as it obtains in the ordinary law of master and servant is quite clear. The master who wrongfully dismisses his servant is bound to pay him such damages as will compensate him for the wrong that he has sustained. They are to be assessed by reference to the amount earned in the service wrongfully terminated and the time likely to elapse before the servant obtains another post for which he is fitted.

arguments.claim: Finding of unfair labour practice and victimization prevents respondent from easily terminating service post-reinstatement

anchor.surface_text: a finding recorded by the Industri- al Tribunal which made the award dated December 5, 1950, that the respondent had been guilty of unfair labour prac- tice and victimization and the ordinary right, which the respondent would have been in a position to exercise,

anchor.surface_text: the findings arrived at by the Industrial Tribunal after due consideration of the correspondence which passed between the parties. We also have perused the said correspondence and we see no reason to disturb those findings. If therefore the appellant

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court perused correspondence and found no reason to disturb Industrial Tribunal's findings on factual questions.

holdings.text: The findings of the Industrial Tribunal that the appellant did not fail to resume duty and thereby did not forfeit his rights under the award are upheld.

anchor.surface_text: the findings arrived at by the Industrial Tribunal after due consideration of the correspondence which passed between the parties. We also have perused the said correspondence and we see no reason to disturb those findings. If therefore the appellant

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court independently reviewed correspondence and concurred with lower tribunal's factual determination.

holdings.text: The respondent's circumstances of transfer of business and closure of branches cannot be availed of to reduce the computation of the benefit of reinstatement.

anchor.surface_text: Even though there was no plea by the respondent in its written statement that there were any circumstances which made it impossible for the respondent to reinstate the appellant in its service except the failure of the appellant

holdings.reasoning_summary: No plea in written statement; correspondence showed respondent insisted on reinstatement at Delhi, not impossibility.

holdings.text: The analogy of s.95 CPC for measuring damages at Rs.1000 is inapplicable even for a statutory obligation of reinstatement.

anchor.surface_text: Even if the direction given by the Industrial Tribunal in its award be treated as a statutory obligation imposed on the respondent, this certainly could not be a measure of compensation or damages and it was fairly conceded by the learned counsel

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inappropriate measure for statutory reinstatement; conceded unsupported by respondent's counsel.

holdings.text: The benefit of reinstatement awarded under an award does not become a term or condition of the contract between the workman and employer.

anchor.surface_text: The benefit of reinstatement which is awarded to a workman under the terms of the award does not become a term or condition of the contract between him and the employer. There is no doubt other reliefs by way of changes in the terms

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished from changes in terms/conditions which may imply contract terms; reinstatement sets aside dismissal without varying contract.

holdings.text: An order of reinstatement sets at naught the wrongful dismissal and reinstates the workman as if the original contract of employment had been continuing, governed by prior terms and conditions.

anchor.surface_text: The effect of an order of reinstatement is merely to set at naught the order of wrongful dismissal of the workman by the employer and to reinstate him in the service of the employer as if the Contract of employment originally entered

holdings.reasoning_summary: No variation in contract terms; merely continues original relations post-dismissal annulment.

holdings.text: The monetary value of reinstatement benefit is not computed on basis of breach of contract, tort, or damages for wrongful dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: The monetary value of the benefits of such reinstatement is therefore to be computed not on the basis of a breach of the contract of employment nor on the basis of a tort alleged to have been committed by the employer by reason

holdings.reasoning_summary: Not damages for breach; specific computation under s.20(2) of benefit value, analogous but distinguished from common law.

holdings.text: Under s.20(2), computation of reinstatement benefit requires considering terms of employment, tenure, termination/resignation/retrenchment possibilities, present value, future disputes, unfair labour practice findings, etc.

anchor.surface_text: s. 20 2 of the Act reads as follows-- Section 20.- Recovery of money due from an employer under an award or decision. 1 Where any workman is entitled to receive from the employer any benefit under an award or decision

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive interpretation: compute value from reinstatement date, factoring all case circumstances including probabilities; analogous to master-servant but comprehensive.

holdings.text: Finding of unfair labour practice and victimization by respondent limits its ordinary right to terminate service post-reinstatement on one month's notice.

anchor.surface_text: a finding recorded by the Industrial Tribunal which made the award dated December 5, 1950, that the respondent had been guilty of unfair labour practice and victimization and the ordinary right, which the respondent would

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior tribunal finding impacts future termination justification; tribunal could reinstate if unjustified.

holdings.text: The money value of the reinstatement benefit is reasonably computed at Rs.12,500.

anchor.surface_text: we have come to the conclusion that having regard to all the circumstances of the case it would be reasonable to compute the benefit of reinstatement which was awarded to the appellant at an amount of Rs. 12,500

holdings.reasoning_summary: Estimate after weighing all factors pro and con, without mathematical exactitude.

holdings.text: The Labour Appellate Tribunal erred in dismissing the appeal as incompetent under s.7 lacking substantial question of law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Supreme Court granted special leave under Art.136 and proceeded to merits.
